ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Laser plasma propulsion generation in nanosecond pulse laser interaction with polyimide film

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The plasma propulsion generated in nanosecond pulse laser interaction with polyimide film is investigated. A comparison of coupling coefficient and specific impulse with glass layer and water layer confinement is given. It shows that polyimide has a higher efficiency in water confinement ablation. Through doped carbon black in polyimide film, a higher coupling coefficient is obtained. In ablated surface images, less re-deposited products on polyimide surface have been observed compared with other polymers at the same laser intensity.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Laser plasma micro-propulsion technology is progressing rapidly due to its unique advantage for creating very small thrusts for precisely positioning micro- and nano-satellites as well as removing orbital debris [1–5]. In laser propulsion, the ablation materials and target configuration are firstly considered for enhancement of the coupling coefficient and specific impulse. Previously, a series of single-pulse material-characterization tests were performed to find optimum propulsion [6–9]. Those tests have identified that a suitable configuration consists of a transparent substrate and an ablation layer, where the plasma induced on the ablation layer is confined by the transparent substrate. It is found that such a confined ablation can significantly enhance the coupling coefficient [10, 11]. It also can avoid target ablation products backstreaming onto the optics. Hence, such a configuration attracts much attention in laser plasma propulsion. The desirable transparent substrates are focused on the polyimide resin and cellulose acetate due to their high transparency and high optical damage threshold. On the other hand, the ablation materials are restricted to those of low thermal conductivity polymers such as polyvinyl chloride (PVC), polyoxymethylene (POM), polyvinyl nitrate (PVN), nitrocellulose (NC) [12–14]. Furthermore, a higher specific impulse of 1,520 s is achieved in laser directly ablated polyimide film through controlling the ablated area [8]. In this paper, a nanosecond laser pulse interaction with polyimide film confined by glass layer as well as water layer is investigated. The coupling coefficient and specific impulse are measured, respectively. Especially, polyimide films doped with different wt% of carbon black is tested to enhance the coupling coefficient. Ablation at different laser shots and laser intensity is performed and less re-deposited products has been observed on the surface images.

Section1.Heading: Experiments
Section1.Para:
In water confinement ablation, the holder is a bulk delrin with 3 mm thickness and diameter of 10 mm. A cavity with depth of 2.5 mm and diameter of 4 mm in it is used to hold the water. A commercial polyimide (PI, C

is placed in the bottom of the cavity. Laser pulses are directly focused by a lens (
$$f=500$$

mm,
$$\Phi =50$$
Φ = 50
mm) on the polyimide through the water. For glass layer confinement ablation, laser pulse is focused on the polyimide film through the glass layer. The schematic target configuration is shown in Fig. 1. The glass layer is fixed by a holder. And the glass layer with the target is not an integrated body. It is tightly contact with the target surface. After the ablation, only the target moves away.
Fig. 1
Target configuration for glass layer confinement ablation (a) and water layer confinement ablation (b)

The pulsed beam used in experiment has a wavelength 532 nm, pulse duration 10 ns, and maximum energy approximately 200 mJ. The target momentum is measured by a photo-electricity device [15]. The schematic of target velocity measurement is shown in Fig. 2. Two He-Ne laser beams of 1 and 2 are used as probe beams to propagate paralleling to the surface of the target and fall into two photodiodes. Two signals of the target pass through two probe beams are recorded by an oscilloscope as shown in Fig. 2. The target velocity is the ratio of the distance between the two beams to the time
$$\Delta t$$
Δ t
between two signals on the oscilloscope. The velocity measured is more accurate than our previous device only one He-Ne beam used [15, 16]. For two probe beams, the target thickness and the probe beam diameter size have no effects on measurement results. The error of this method comparison with its theoretical value is less than 2 % [17].
Fig. 2
The schematic of target velocity measurement. The time
$$\Delta t$$
Δ t
marked in the oscilloscope is the time for target pass through beam 1 and beam 2

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 3 shows the coupling coefficient generation at different laser energy in water and glass layer confinement ablation. The coupling coefficient is defined as the ratio of the target momentum generation by the plasma to the incident laser energy. It is clearly seen that the coupling coefficient present a decrease tendency with the laser energy. And the water is more effectively than the glass layer to enhance the coupling coefficient. For example, with the laser energy of 53 mJ, the coupling coefficient is 308 and 116 dyne/W for water and glass layer respectively.
Fig. 3
Coupling coefficient generation at different laser energy in glass layer and water layer confinement ablation

The specific impulse is defined as the ratio of the coupling coefficient to the ablated consumption mass. The specific impulse and the coupling coefficient are both the most important parameters evaluated in laser propulsion, but it shows that a high specific impulse is more meaningful in propulsion, which means a longer life span and more efficient load. Because the amount of material removed is in the microgram range and impossible to measure directly in this experiment, it is deduced from the size of the crater produced in the film surface using a microscope. Figure 4 shows the specific impulse of the laser ablation of polyimide film with water and glass layer confinement. More than 7,000 s of the specific impulse is found in glass layer confinement ablation. And the specific impulse increases with the laser energy. For the water served as the confinement layer, the specific impulse is only tens of second. And the specific impulse presents a decrease tendency.
Fig. 4
Specific impulse generation at different laser energy in glass layer and water layer confinement ablation

It can be seen that one increases and the other decreases between the specific impulse and the coupling coefficient. A direct relationship between the specific impulse and coupling coefficient is given in Fig. 5. The data in Fig. 5 comes from the Figs. 3 and 4. It can be seen that it is agreement with the inverse proportional relationship for glass layer confinement ablation Fig. 5a. But for water layer, the coupling coefficient and specific impulse present a similar tendency Fig. 5b. A low coupling coefficient does not mean a high specific impulse. In water confinement ablation and other liquid propellant, target momentum comes from two parts: one is plasma expansion and the other is the splashing of the unionized liquid material. In this experiment, the latter play a determinable role, which results in a very low specific impulse. One important reason of a higher specific impulse near 7,000 s obtained in experiment is due the fixed glass layer. According to the momentum conservation law, in the ablation process, the glass layer and the target are obtained momentum respectively. Because the glass layer is fixed, the target will obtain more momentum. This results in a higher target coupling coefficient as well as a higher specific impulse [18].
Fig. 5
A relationship between the coupling coefficient and specific impulse for glass layer confinement ablation (a) and water layer confinement ablation (b). The data are obtained from Figs. 3 and 4.
$$C_\mathrm{m}$$
C m
and
$$I_\mathrm{sp}$$
I sp
in inset is the coupling coefficient and specific impulse respectively

For the target materials, it is natural to prefer metal as the propellant. The metal has an extremely low penetration depth, most of the incident energy can be absorbed on the surface and the very high exhaust velocity of jet can provide a high specific impulse. But due to its higher thermal conductivity, the intensity threshold to generation plasma is much higher. General speaking, the threshold of the polymer is in the
$$10^{6}$$
10 6
–
$$10^{8}$$
10 8
W/cm
$$^{2}$$
2
. The threshold of the metal is in the
$$10^{10}$$
10 10
–
$$10^{14}$$
10 14
W/cm
$$^{2}$$
2
. The intensity threshold to generation plasma of the metal material with a high thermal conductivity is tens of time higher than that of low thermal conductivity at the same experimental conductions. The coupling coefficient of laser ablation aluminum is about 10–15 dyne/W in the similar experimental conditions. The specific impulse of aluminum is not obtained due to the mass dissipation so smaller that it is not enough to be measured in our experiment. It is known that smaller mass dissipation, larger specific impulse. This indicates that the specific impulse of aluminum is much higher than that of the polyimide. In contrast to the metal material, polyimide has a rather high penetration depth to the laser radiation, which results in a large amount of mass dissipation and a relatively low specific impulse. But the specific impulse can be enhanced by design a reasonable target configuration. In our early work [8], a higher specific impulse up to 1,520 s is achieved through control the ablated area.

In order to enhance the coupling coefficient, polyimide films doped with different weight content of carbon black are composed and tested as shown in Fig. 6. It shows that a higher coupling coefficient of 263 dyne/W is observed with weight content of 5 % carbon black comparison with pure polyimide film of 119 dyne/W. It indicates that the carbon black can efficiently enhance the laser energy absorption. From this point, some materials with high absorption efficiency for irradiation wavelength as well as releasing energy in interaction such as energy-contain polymers maybe the most potential material serving as the doped component.
Fig. 6
Coupling coefficient generation in polyimide film with different wt% carbon content. The inset is the relative transmissivity of the film for 532 nm irradiation wavelength

Figure 7 shows surface images of polyimide film ablation at different laser shots and intensity. It can be seen that less re-deposited solid products on the surface are observed compared with other polymer such as the polythene [19]. Solid re-products generation in ablation is relative with the interaction mechanism and laser pulse duration [20–22]. A photochemical mechanism leads to a more uniform decomposition of the polymer into small fragments. And less material is re-deposited [21]. From this view, it indicates that the photochemical mechanism plays a determinant role in this ablation. Another reason is the laser duration is nanosecond in this experiment. For a long laser pulse duration such as CO
$$_{2}$$
2
laser with a microsecond duration, more re-deposited products will be observed due to the characteristics photochemical and photothermal length scales is in the same order [20, 22].

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Plasma propulsion generation from polyimide film ablation by nanosecond pulse laser is measured in this experiment. A comparison of coupling coefficient and specific impulse with glass layer and water layer confinement is given. It shows that polyimide has a higher efficiency in water severed as the confinement material. But due to the splashing behavior, a smaller specific impulse is presented. This can be enhanced by the liquid material property such as the viscosity. For example, the coupling coefficient and specific impulse can be linearly enhanced by increasing the viscosity [5]. For polyimide, a less re-deposited solid product is observed in ablated surface images than other polymers such as polythene at the same laser intensity.
